utterances: For a doctor in a small town like this, sometimes practicing medicine means more than writing prescriptions and applying bandages.
Everyone is on edge as inspectors make their way door to door to determine if the houses are safe to live in, a colored sticker sealing your fate.
Many of the wooden clapboard homes have been in families for generations and are not insured.
In front of one of those homes, a woman sits at a picnic table spreading out water stained photographs, faded baby announcements and soaked newspaper clippings.
I'm trying to save my mother's pictures, some of her pictures that she has lost and cleaning her house out, that she has nothing left.
Myself, I've lost everything here, too.
So we're just down here trying to clean everything up and trying to get our life back together here in the bayou.
Lillian Marbant was born in this house 44 years ago.
Her deeply lined tanned face reveals a lifetime of hard work and hard times.
She was living in this small three-bedroom home with her mother and 13 other relatives.
Now all their belongings are heaped into a big trash pile out front.
Do you mind showing me what happened here?
Come on in.
We've gotten just about it all cleaned up, but I want to show you on this wall about how far the water--'cause you can mainly see the waterline.
It got about right here.
There's our waterline right there.
Which is up to your shoulders.
Uh-huh.
And there's all this muck...
Right.
Right.
...and leaves and stuff all stuck to the walls.
It has been so nasty in here just the things that we pulled out this morning.
Oh, it made me sick to my stomach.
It's just pure rotten.
I've been hearing that a lot of people in this town were just struggling anyway with the way the industry was and stuff and then now this.
Yeah, shrimping had gotten to where it was really too much of that not going, you know, on too much.
The fuel's gotten up so high and the price of shrimp has dropped and then it's summertime.
Oysters wasn't really that great, you know, and it's just been rough.
It has for a lot of people.
(Soundbite of water)
Already there are small signs of people getting back to what they know best here.
As we stand with Dr. Benjamin at the mouth of Bayou La Batre, there's a shrimp boat returning to port and a little boy fishing with his dad on the end of the jetty.
Dr. Benjamin says the scene is odd.
Usually you would see in the evenings lots of shrimp boats coming back in, in the afternoons, but you only see one little boat coming.
They just caught a fish.
I wonder what kind it is.
And the little kid is happy he caught a fish.
A pretty big fish.

When you were giving us our tour and every few feet we were seeing these shrimp boats piled one on another and we were seeing that the industries along this bayou all gutted, is it overwhelming at some point to think what has to happen to make this place work again?
It's starting to sink in just how much it's going to really hurt in the long term.
We don't have deaths.
We don't have--we can rebuild a building but you can never replace a life.
And so in that respect, I think we really were blessed, but the economic and the day to day full force of it is just starting to sink in.
It's just starting to sink in to me.
And that's what's really going to be troubling in the next few months.
It's going to be harder and harder as the days go by and bills start to pile up.
It's going to be tough.
It's unimaginable, but it has to be done.
And you just move one boat at a time, one building at a time, one person at a time.
And the same thing with health care.
You make sure one person at a time is healthy, that they're safe, that they're getting the primary care that they need, they're getting the specialists that they need, and you do it one at a time.
(Soundbite of water)
Dr.
Regina Benjamin is awaiting the delivery of a temporary trailer to reopen her family practice in Bayou La Batre, Alabama.
She's hoping it will arrive today.
Meanwhile, several national health-care groups have launched a fund-raising campaign to rebuild her clinic.
(Soundbite of water)
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Jennifer Ludden.
The eye of Hurricane Dennis came ashore just east of Pensacola, Florida, a little before 2:30 this afternoon local time.
The storm was blamed for at least 20 deaths in Haiti and Cuba.
But after it hit those islands, Dennis weakened substantially.
As it crossed the Gulf of Mexico, the storm then gathered strength to a powerful Category 4 storm.
Then just before coming ashore today, winds again diminished.
Hurricane Dennis was a compact storm.
Still, at its strongest, four-story-high waves splashed over seawalls, and there are power and water outages in the area.
Sandra Averhart of member station WUWF in Pensacola joins me now.
Hi, Sandra.
Hello there.
It's been more than five hours now since the storm hit right where you are.
What are officials saying about damage?
Other witnesses heard the quote slightly differently, but they say the meaning was clear.
Mahmud, the local imam, said he spotted a passing police van.
So we flagged them down.
We told them the situation, that there's a man.
He's restrained.
And there's a mob attempting to hurt him.
If you don't take him, God forbid, he might be seriously hurt.
The legend of La Kahena, which provides the title for Cheb i Sabbah's album, lies at the heart of these cultural unions and conflicts.
La Kahena was a 7th-century warrior queen of the Berbers and led a huge army that repelled a Muslim invasion.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing in foreign language)
Sensing a second Muslim attack, La Kahena ordered the destruction of her homeland's cities and orchards to diminish the land's valley to the Muslims.
The move backfired, and she lost the support of many of her people.
Legend has it that she was captured and beheaded by the Arabs and that her sons later embraced Islam, paving the way for the Muslim presence in the region today.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing in foreign language)
La Kahena herself is reputed to be of Jewish descent.
The mixture of faiths, as well as the subtle interplay of accommodation and resistance, makes La Kahena's story relevant today, particularly for the region's women.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing in foreign language)
I chose La Kahena as a, you know, symbolic, I think, posture in history of woman and woman, because a conception also is that women in the Arab world are less than wherever else.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing in foreign language)
The album was recorded mostly in a home studio, deep in the medina of Marrakesh, Morocco.
Nearly all the vocals are sung by women.
One featured group, B'net Marrakech, is famous for preserving past disappearing traditions and began singing long before it was socially acceptable.

Traditionally, you know, within Arab and Muslim culture, the woman that sings is not someone you would want to marry because it's--you know, it's like, no, you don't want your wife to be, you know, performing and singing and all that traditionally, our world that is changing.
Singer Khadija Othmani represents another musical element of the Maghreb on this album: the sub-Saharan tinde traditions, as heard on ""Alkher Illa Doffor,"" which means peace is found behind wounds.
(Soundbite of ""Alkher Illa Doffor"")
